div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS OF Rossillion, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: And I in going, madam, weep o'er my father's
death anew: but I must attend his majesty's
command, to whom I am now in ward, evermore in
subjection.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: You shall find of the king a husband, madam; you,
sir, a father: he that so generally is at all
times good must of necessity hold his virtue to
you; whose worthiness would stir it up where it
wanted rather than lack it where there is such
abundance.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: What hope is there of his majesty's amendment?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: He hath abandoned his physicians, madam; under
whose practices he hath persecuted time with
hope, and finds no other advantage in the process but
only the losing of hope by time.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: This young gentlewoman had a father, â O that âhadâ!
how sad a passage 'tis! â whose skill was almost
as great as his honesty; had it stretched so far,
would have made nature immortal, and death should
have play for lack of work. Would, for the king's
sake, he were living! I think it would be the death of
the king's disease.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: How called you the man you speak of, madam?

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it was his
great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: He was excellent indeed, madam: the king very
lately spoke of him admiringly and mourningly:
he was skilful enough to have lived still, if
knowledge could be set up against mortality.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: What is it, my good lord, the king languishes of?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: A fistula, my lord.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I heard not of it before.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman
the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my
overlooking. I have those hopes of her good that
her education promises; her dispositions she
inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer; for
where an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities,
there commendations go with pity; they are virtues
and traitors too; in her they are the better for
their simpleness; she derives her honesty and achieves
her goodness.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Your commendations, madam, get from her tears.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: 'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise
in. The remembrance of her father never approaches
her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows takes
all livelihood from her cheek. No more of this,
Helena; go to, no more; lest it be rather thought you
affect a sorrow than to have â

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,
excessive grief the enemy to the living.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: If the living be enemy to the grief, the excess makes
it soon mortal.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: How understand we that?

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father
in manners, as in shape! thy blood and virtue
Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness
Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few,
Do wrong to none: be able for thine enemy
Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend
Under thy own life's key; be checked for silence,
But never taxed for speech. What heaven more will,
That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down,
Fall on thy head! Farewell, my lord;
'Tis an unseasoned courtier; good my lord,
Advise him.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: He cannot want the best
That shall attend his love.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: The best wishes that can be forged in your thoughts
be servants to you!
Be comfortable to my mother, your mistress, and make
much of her.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Farewell, pretty lady: you must hold the credit of
your father.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: O, were that all! I think not on my father;
And these great tears grace his remembrance more
Than those I shed for him. What was he like?
I have forgot him: my imagination
Carries no favour in't but Bertram's.
I am undone: there is no living, none,
If Bertram be away. 'Twere all one
That I should love a bright particular star
And think to wed it, he is so above me:
In his bright radiance and collateral light
Must I be comforted, not in his sphere.
The ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
The hind that would be mated by the lion
Must die for love. 'Twas pretty, though a plague,
To see him every hour; to sit and draw
His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls,
In our heart's table; heart too capable
Of every line and trick of his sweet favour:
But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy
Must sanctify his reliques. Who comes here? Enter PAROLLES. Aside
One that goes with him: I love him for his sake;
And yet I know him a notorious liar,
Think him a great way fool, solely a coward;
Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him,
That they take place, when virtue's steely bones
Looks bleak i' the cold wind: withal, full oft we see
Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Save you, fair queen!

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: And you, monarch!

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: No.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: And no.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Are you meditating on virginity?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you: let
me ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity; how
may we barricado it against him?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Keep him out.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: But he assails; and our virginity, though valiant,
in the defence yet is weak: unfold to us some warlike
resistance.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: There is none: man, setting down before you, will
undermine you and blow you up.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: Bless our poor virginity from underminers and
blowers-up! Is there no military policy, how virgins
might blow up men?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier
be blown up: marry, in blowing him down again,
with the breach yourselves made, you lose your
city. It is not politic in the commonwealth of
nature to preserve virginity. Loss of virginity
is rational increase and there was never virgin
got till virginity was first lost. That you were
made of is metal to make virgins. Virginity by
being once lost may be ten times found; by being
ever kept, it is ever lost: 'tis too cold a companion;
away with't!

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: I will stand for't a little, though therefore I die a
virgin.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: There's little can be said in't; 'tis against
the rule of nature. To speak on the part of
virginity, is to accuse your mothers; which is
most infallible disobedience. He that hangs
himself is a virgin; virginity murders itself
and should be buried in highways out of all
sanctified limit, as a desperate offendress
against nature. Virginity breeds mites, much like
a cheese; consumes itself to the very paring,
and so dies with feeding his own stomach. Besides,
virginity is peevish, proud, idle, made of
self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in
the canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but
lose by't: out with't! within th' one year it
will make itself two, which is a goodly increase;
and the principal itself not much the worse: away
with't!

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Let me see: marry, ill, to like him that ne'er
it likes. 'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss
with lying; the longer kept, the less worth: off
with't while 'tis vendible; answer the time of
request. Virginity, like an old courtier, wears
her cap out of fashion: richly suited, but
unsuitable: just like the brooch and the toothpick,
which wear not now. Your date is better in your
pie and your porridge than in your cheek: and
your virginity, your old virginity is like one
of our French withered pears, it looks ill, it
eats drily; marry, 'tis a withered pear; it was
formerly better; marry, yet 'tis a withered pear: will
you any thing with it?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Not my virginity yet, â¦
There shall your master have a thousand loves,
A mother and a mistress and a friend,
A phoenix, captain and an enemy,
A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign,
A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear;
His humble ambition, proud humility,
His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet,
His faith, his sweet disaster; with a world
Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms,
That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he â
I know not what he shall. God send him well!
The court's a learning place, and he is one â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: What one, i' faith?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: That I wish well. 'Tis pity â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: What's pity?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: That wishing well had not a body in't,
Which might be felt; that we, the poorer born,
Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,
Might with effects of them follow our friends,
And show what we alone must think, which never
Returns us thanks. Enter Page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Monsieur Parolles, my lord calls for you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Little Helen, farewell; if I can remember thee, I will
think of thee at court.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a charitable
star.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Under Mars, I.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: I especially think, under Mars.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Why under Mars?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: The wars hath so kept you under that you must needs be
born under Mars.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: When he was predominant.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: When he was retrograde, I think, rather.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: You go so much backward when you fight.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: That's for advantage.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: So is running away, when fear proposes the safety:
but the composition that your valour and fear
makes in you is a virtue of a good wing, and I like
the wear well.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I am so full of businesses, I cannot answer thee
acutely. I will return perfect courtier; in the
which, my instruction shall serve to naturalize
thee, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier's
counsel and understand what advice shall thrust
upon thee; else thou diest in thine unthankfulness,
and thine ignorance makes thee away: farewell.
When thou hast leisure, say thy prayers; when
thou hast none, remember thy friends: get thee
a good husband, and use him as he uses thee; so
farewell.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie.
Which we ascribe to heaven: the fated sky
Gives us free scope, only doth backward pull
Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.
What power is it which mounts my love so high,
That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye?
The mightiest space in fortune nature brings
To join like likes and kiss like native things.
Impossible be strange attempts to those
That weigh their pains in sense and do suppose
What hath been cannot be: who ever strove
To show her merit, that did miss her love?
The king's disease â my project may deceive me,
But my intents are fixed and will not leave me. Exit.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter the KING OF FRANCE, with letters, and divers Attendants.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The Florentines and Senoys are by the ears;
Have fought with equal fortune and continue
A braving war.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: So 'tis reported, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nay, 'tis most credible; we here receive it
A certainty, vouched from our cousin Austria,
With caution that the Florentine will move us
For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend
Prejudicates the business and would seem
To have us make denial.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: His love and wisdom,
Approved so to your majesty, may plead
For amplest credence.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He hath armed our answer,
And Florence is denied before he comes:
Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to see
The Tuscan service, freely have they leave
To stand on either part.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: It well may serve
A nursery to our gentry, who are sick
For breathing and exploit.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What's he comes here? Enter BERTRAM, LAFEU, and PAROLLES.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: It is the Count Rossillion, my good lord,
Young Bertram.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face;
Frank nature, rather curious than in haste,
Hath well composed thee. Thy father's moral parts
Mayst thou inherit too! Welcome to Paris.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: My thanks and duty are your majesty's.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I would I had that corporal soundness now,
As when thy father and myself in friendship
First tried our soldiership! He did look far
Into the service of the time and was
Discipled of the bravest: he lasted long;
But on us both did haggish age steal on
And wore us out of act. It much repairs me
To talk of your good father. In his youth
He had the wit which I can well observe
to-day in our young lords; but they may jest
Till their own scorn return to them unnoted
Ere they can hide their levity in honour:
So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness
Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were,
His equal had awaked them, and his honour,
Clock to itself, knew the true minute when
Exception bid him speak, and at this time
His tongue obeyed his hand: who were below him
He used as creatures of another place
And bowed his eminent top to their low ranks,
Making them proud of his humility,
In their poor praise he humbled. Such a man
Might be a copy to these younger times;
Which, followed well, would demonstrate them now
But goers backward.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: His good remembrance, sir,
Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb;
So in approof lives not his epitaph
As in your royal speech.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Would I were with him! He would always say â
Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words
He scattered not in ears, but grafted them,
To grow there and to bear, â âLet me not live,â â
This his good melancholy oft began,
On the catastrophe and heel of pastime,
When it was out, â âLet me not live,â quoth he,
âAfter my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff
Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
All but new things disdain; whose judgements are
Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies
Expire before their fashions.â This he wished:
I after him do after him wish too,
Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home,
I quickly were dissolved from my hive,
To give some labourers room.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: You're loved, sir:
They that least lend it you shall lack you first.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I fill a place, I know't. How long is't, count,
Since the physician at your father's died?
He was much famed.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Some six months since, my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: If he were living, I would try him yet.
Lend me an arm; the rest have worn me out
With several applications: nature and sickness
Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, count;
My son's no dearer.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Thank your majesty. Exeunt. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: I will now hear; what say you of this gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.ab: Madam, the care I have had to even your content,
I wish might be found in the calendar of my past
endeavours; for then we wound our modesty and
make foul the clearness of our deservings, when of
ourselves we publish them.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: What does this knave here? Get you gone, sirrah:
the complaints I have heard of you I do not all
believe; 'tis my slowness that I do not; for I
know you lack not folly to commit them, and have
ability enough to make such knaveries yours.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: 'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: No, madam, 'tis not so well that I am poor, though
many of the rich are damned: but, if I may have
your ladyship's good will to go to the world, Isbel
the woman and I will do as we may.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I do beg your good will in this case.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: In what case?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: In Isbel's case and mine own. Service is no
heritage: and I think I shall never have the
blessing of God till I have issue a' my body; for they
say barnes are blessings.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: My poor body, madam, requires it: I am driven on
by the flesh; and he must needs go that the devil
drives.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Is this all your worship's reason?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons, such as they
are.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: May the world know them?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you
and all flesh and blood are; and, indeed, I do marry
that I may repent.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Thy marriage, sooner than thy wickedness.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I am out a' friends, madam; and I hope to have friends
for my wife's sake.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Y' are shallow, madam, in great friends; for the
knaves come to do that for me which I am aweary
of. He that ears my land spares my team and gives
me leave to inn the crop; if I be his cuckold,
he's my drudge: he that comforts my wife is the
cherisher of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes
my flesh and blood loves my flesh and blood; he
that loves my flesh and blood is my friend: ergo,
he that kisses my wife is my friend. If men could
be contented to be what they are, there were no
fear in marriage; for young Charbon the Puritan
and old Poysam the papist, howsome'er their hearts
are severed in religion, their heads are both
one; they may jowl horns together, like any deer i'
the herd.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouthed and calumnious knave?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: A prophet I, madam; and I speak the truth the next
way:

lg.l: For I the ballad will repeat,
Which men full true shall find;
Your marriage comes by dest'ny,
Your cuckoo sings by kind.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Get you gone, sir; I'll talk with you more anon.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.ab: May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come to
you: of her I am to speak.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I would speak with her;
Helen, I mean.

lg.l: Was this fair face the cause, quoth she,
Why the Grecians sacked Troy?
Fond done, done fond,
Was this King Priam's joy?
With that she sighed as she stood,
With that she sighed as she stood,
And gave this sentence then;
Among nine bad if one be good,
Among nine bad if one be good,
There's yet one good in ten.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: What, one good in ten? you corrupt the song, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: One good woman in ten, madam; which is a purifying
a' the song: would God would serve the world so
all the year; we'ld find no fault with the
tithe-woman, if I were the parson. One in ten,
quoth 'a! An we might have a good woman born but
or every blazing star, or at an earthquake,
'twould mend the lottery well: a man may draw his
heart out, ere 'a pluck one.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: You'll be gone, sir knave, and do as I command you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: That man should be at woman's command, and yet
no hurt done! Though honesty be no puritan, yet
it will do no hurt; it will wear the surplice of
humility over the black gown of a big heart. I
am going, forsooth: the business is for Helen to come
hither.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Well, now.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.ab: I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman entirely.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Faith, I do: her father bequeathed her to me;
and she herself, without other advantage, may
lawfully make title to as much love as she finds:
there is more owing her than is paid; and more shall
be paid her than she'll demand.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.ab: Madam, I was very late more near her than I think
she wished me: alone she was, and did communicate
to herself her own words to her own ears; she
thought, I dare vow for her, they touched not
any stranger sense. Her matter was, she loved
your son: Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that
had put such difference betwixt their two estates;
Love no god, that would not extend his might,
only where qualities were level; Dian no queen
of virgins, that would suffer her poor knight
surprised, without rescue in the first assault
or ransom afterward. This she delivered in the
most bitter touch of sorrow that e'er I heard
virgin exclaim in: which I held my duty speedily
to acquaint you withal; sithence, in the loss
that may happen, it concerns you something to know it.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: You have discharged this honestly; keep it to
yourself: many likelihoods informed me of this
before, which hung so tottering in the balance
that I could neither believe nor misdoubt. Pray
you, leave me: stall this in your bosom; and I
thank you for your honest care: I will speak with you
further anon.
sp.l: Even so it was with me when I was young:
If ever we are nature's, these are ours; this thorn
Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong;
Our blood to us, this to our blood is born;
It is the show and seal of nature's truth,
Where love's strong passion is impressed in youth:
By our remembrances of days forgone,
Such were our faults, or then we thought them none.
Her eye is sick on't: I observe her now.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: What is your pleasure, madam?

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: You know, Helen,
I am a mother to you.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Mine honourable mistress.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Nay, a mother:
Why not a mother? When I said âa mother,â
Methought you saw a serpent: what's in âmother,â
That you start at it? I say, I am your mother;
And put you in the catalogue of those
That were enwombed mine: 'tis often seen
Adoption strives with nature and choice breeds
A native slip to us from foreign seeds:
You ne'er oppressed me with a mother's groan,
Yet I express to you a mother's care:
God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blood
To say I am thy mother? What's the matter,
That this distempered messenger of wet
The many-coloured Iris, rounds thine eye?
Why? that you are my daughter?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: That I am not.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: I say, I am your mother.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Pardon, madam;
The Count Rossillion cannot be my brother:
I am from humble, he from honoured name;
No note upon my parents, his all noble:
My master, my dear lord he is; and I
His servant live, and will his vassal die:
He must not be my brother.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Nor I your mother?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: You are my mother, madam; would you were, â
So that my lord your son were not my brother, â
Indeed my mother or were you both our mothers,
I care no more for than I do for heaven,
So I were not his sister. Can't no other,
But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law:
God shield you mean it not! daughter and mother
So strive upon your pulse. What, pale again?
My fear hath catched your fondness: now I see
The mystery of your loneliness, and find
Your salt tears' head: now to all sense 'tis gross
You love my son; invention is ashamed,
Against the proclamation of thy passion,
To say thou dost not: therefore tell me true;
But, tell me then, 'tis so; for, look, thy cheeks
Confess it, th' one to th' other; and thine eyes
See it so grossly shown in thy behaviours
That in their kind they speak it: only sin
And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue,
That truth should be suspected. Speak, is't so?
If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew;
If it be not, forswear't: howe'er, I charge thee,
As heaven shall work in me for thine avail,
To tell me truly.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Good madam, pardon me!

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Do you love my son?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Your pardon, noble mistress!

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Love you my son?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Do not you love him, madam?

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Go not about; my love hath in't a bond,
Whereof the world takes note: come, come, disclose
The state of your affection; for your passions
Have to the full appeached.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Then, I confess,
Here on my knee, before high heaven and you,
That before you, and next unto high heaven,
I love your son.
My friends were poor, but honest; so's my love:
Be not offended; for it hurts not him
That he is loved of me: I follow him not
By any token of presumptuous suit;
Nor would I have him till I do deserve him;
Yet never know how that desert should be.
I know I love in vain, strive against hope;
Yet in this captious and intenible sieve
I still pour in the waters of my love
And lack not to lose still: thus, Indian-like,
Religious in mine error, I adore
The sun, that looks upon his worshipper,
But knows of him no more. My dearest madam,
Let not your hate encounter with my love
For loving where you do: but if yourself,
Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth,
Did ever in so true a flame of liking
Wish chastely and love dearly, that your Dian
Was both herself and love; O, then, give pity
To her, whose state is such that cannot choose
But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
That seeks not to find that her search implies,
But riddle-like lives sweetly where she dies!

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Had you not lately an intent, â speak truly, â
To go to Paris?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Madam, I had.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Wherefore? tell true.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear.
You know my father left me some prescriptions
Of rare and proved effects, such as his reading
And manifest experience had collected
For general sovereignty; and that he willed me
In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them,
As notes whose faculties inclusive were
More than they were in note: amongst the rest
There is a remedy, approved, set down,
To cure the desperate languishings whereof
The king is rendered lost.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: This was your motive
For Paris, was it? speak.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: My lord your son made me to think of this;
Else Paris and the medicine and the king
Had from the conversation of my thoughts
Haply been absent then.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: But think you, Helen,
If you should tender your supposed aid,
He would receive it? he and his physicians
Are of a mind; he, that they cannot help him,
They, that they cannot help: how shall they credit
A poor unlearned virgin, when the schools,
Embowelled of their doctrine, have left off
The danger to itself?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: There's something in't,
More than my father's skill, which was the greatest
Of his profession, that his good receipt
Shall for my legacy be sanctified
By the luckiest stars in heaven: and, would your honour
But give me leave to try success, I'ld venture
The well-lost life of mine on his grace's cure
By such a day and hour.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Dost thou believe't?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Ay, madam, knowingly.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love,
Means and attendants and my loving greetings
To those of mine in court: I'll stay at home
And pray God's blessing into thy attempt:
Be gone to-morrow; and be sure of this,
What I can help thee to thou shalt not miss. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Farewell, young lords; these warlike principles
Do not throw from you: and you, my lords, farewell:
Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain, all
The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis received,
And is enough for both.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: 'Tis our hope, sir,
After well-entered soldiers, to return
And find your grace in health.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart
Will not confess he owes the malady
That doth my life besiege. Farewell, young lords;
Whether I live or die, be you the sons
Of worthy Frenchmen: let higher Italy, â
Those bated that inherit but the fall
Of the last monarchy, â see that you come
Not to woo honour, but to wed it: when
The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek,
That fame may cry you loud: I say, farewell.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Health, at your bidding, serve your majesty!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Those girls of Italy, take heed of them:
They say, our French lack language to deny,
If they demand: beware of being captives,
Before you serve.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: Our hearts receive your warnings.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Farewell. Come hither to me. Exit, attended.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: O my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: 'Tis not his fault, the spark.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: O, 'tis brave wars!

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Most admirable: I have seen those wars.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I am commanded here, and kept a coil with
âToo youngâ and âthe next yearâ and 'tis too early.â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: An thy mind stand to't boy, steal away bravely.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock,
Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry,
Till honour be bought up and no sword worn
But one to dance with! By heaven, I'll steal away.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: There's honour in the theft.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Commit it, count.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: I am your accessory; and so, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I grow to you, and our parting is a tortured body.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Farewell, captain.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Sweet Monsieur Parolles!

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin. Good
sparks and lustrous, a word, good metals: you
shall find in the regiment of the Spinii one
Captain Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of
war, here on his sinister cheek; it was this very
sword entrenched it: say to him, I live; and observe
his reports for me.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: We shall, noble captain.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Mars dote on you for his novices! what will ye do?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Stay: the king.
sp.stage: Re-enter KING. BERTRAM and PAROLLES retire.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble lords;
you have restrained yourself within the list of
too cold an adieu: be more expressive to them:
for they wear themselves in the cap of the time,
there do muster true gait, eat, speak, and move
under the influence of the most received star;
and though the devil lead the measure, such are
to be followed: after them, and take a more dilated
farewell.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: And I will do so.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Worthy fellows; and like to prove most sinewy
swordmen.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I'll see thee to stand up.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Then here's a man stands, that has brought his pardon.
I would you had kneeled, my lord, to ask me mercy,
And that at my bidding you could so stand up.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I would I had; so I had broke thy pate,
And asked thee mercy for't.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Good faith, across:
But, my good lord, 'tis thus: will you be cured
of your infirmity?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: O, will you eat
No grapes, my royal fox? Yes, but you will
My noble grapes, an if my royal fox
Could reach them: I have seen a medicine
That's able to breathe life into a stone,
Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary
With sprightly fire and motion; whose simple touch
Is powerful to araise King Pepin, nay,
To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand
And write to her a love-line.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What âherâ is this?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Why, Doctor She: my lord, there's one arrived,
If you will see her: now, by my faith and honour,
If seriously I may convey my thoughts
In this my light deliverance, I have spoke
With one that, in her sex, her years, profession,
Wisdom and constancy, hath amazed me more
Than I dare blame my weakness: will you see her,
For that is her demand, and know her business?
That done, laugh well at me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now, good Lafeu,
Bring in the admiration; that we with thee
May spend our wonder too, or take off thine
By wondering how thou took'st it.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Nay, I'll fit you,
And not be all day neither. Exit.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues. Re-enter LAFEU, with HELENA.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Nay, come your ways.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This haste hath wings indeed.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Nay, come your ways;
This is his majesty; say your mind to him:
A traitor you do look like; but such traitors
His majesty seldom fears: I am Cressid's uncle,
That dare leave two together; fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now, fair one, does your business follow us?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Ay, my good lord.
Gerard de Narbon was my father;
In what he did profess, well found.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I knew him.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: The rather will I spare my praises towards him;
Knowing him is enough. On's bed of death
Many receipts he gave me; chiefly one,
Which, as the dearest issue of his practice,
And of his old experience the only darling,
He bade me store up, as a triple eye,
Safer than mine own two, more dear; I have so;
And, hearing your high majesty is touched
With that malignant cause wherein the honour
Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power,
I come to tender it and my appliance
With all bound humbleness.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We thank you, maiden;
But may not be so credulous of cure,
When our most learned doctors leave us and
The congregated college have concluded
That labouring art can never ransom nature
From her inaidible estate; I say we must not
So stain our judgement, or corrupt our hope,
To prostitute our past-cure malady
To empirics, or to dissever so
Our great self and our credit, to esteem
A senseless help which help past sense we deem.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: My duty then shall pay me for my pains:
I will no more enforce mine office on you;
Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts
A modest one, to bear me back again.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I cannot give thee less, to be called grateful:
Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give
As one near death to those that wish him live:
But what at full I know, thou know'st no part,
I knowing all my peril, thou no art.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: What I can do can do no hurt to try,
Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy.
He that of greatest works is finisher
Oft does them by the weakest minister:
So holy writ in babes hath judgement shown,
When judges have been babes; great floods have flown
From simple sources, and great seas have dried
When miracles have by the greatest been denied.
Oft expectation fails and most oft there
Where most it promises, and oft it hits
Where hope is coldest and despair most fits.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I must not hear thee; fare thee well, kind maid;
Thy pains not used must by thyself be paid:
Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Inspired merit so by breath is barred:
It is not so with Him that all things knows
As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows;
But most it is presumption in us when
The help of heaven we count the act of men.
Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent;
Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
I am not an impostor that proclaim
Myself against the level of mine aim;
But know I think and think I know most sure
My art is not past power nor you past cure.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Art thou so confident? within what space
Hopest thou my cure?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: The great'st grace lending grace,
Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring,
Ere twice in murk and occidental damp
Moist Hesperus hath quenched her sleepy lamp,
Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass
Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass.
What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly,
Health shall live free and sickness freely die.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Upon thy certainty and confidence
What darest thou venture?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Tax of impudence,
A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame
Traduced by odious ballads: my maiden's name
Seared otherwise; ne, worse of worst â extended
With vilest torture let my life be ended.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
His powerful sound within an organ weak:
And what impossibility would slay
In common sense, sense saves another way.
Thy life is dear; for all that life can rate
Worth name of life in thee hath estimate,
Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all
That happiness and prime can happy call:
Thou this to hazard needs must intimate
Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.
Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try,
That ministers thine own death if I die.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: If I break time, or flinch in property
Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die,
And well deserved: not helping, death's my fee;
But, if I help, what do you promise me?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Make thy demand.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: But will you make it even?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand
What husband in thy power I will command:
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To choose from forth the royal blood of France,
My low and humble name to propagate
With any branch or image of thy state;
But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know
Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Here is my hand; the premises observed,
Thy will by my performance shall be served:
So make the choice of thy own time, for I,
Thy resolved patient, on thee still rely.
More should I question thee, and more I must,
Though more to know could not be more to trust,
From whence thou camest, how tended on: but rest
Unquestioned welcome and undoubted blest.
Give me some help here, ho! If thou proceed
As high as word, my deed shall match thy deed. Flourish. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Come on, sir; I shall now put you to the height of
your breeding.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught: I know
my business is but to the court.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: To the court! why, what place make you special,
when you put off that with such contempt? But to the
court!

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners,
he may easily put it off at court: he that cannot
make a leg, put off's cap, kiss his hand and say
nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap;
and indeed such a fellow, to say precisely, were
not for the court; but for me, I have an answer will
serve all men.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Marry, that's a bountiful answer that fits all
questions.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: It is like a barber's chair that fits all buttocks,
the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock, the
brawn-buttock, or any buttock.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Will your answer serve fit to all questions?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an
attorney, as your French crown for your taffeta
punk, as Tib's rush for Tom's forefinger, as a
pancake for Shrove Tuesday, a morris for May-day,
as the nail to his hole, the cuckold to his horn,
as a scolding quean to a wrangling knave, as the
nun's lip to the friar's mouth, nay, as the pudding to
his skin.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness for all
questions?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: From below your duke to beneath your constable, it
will fit any question.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must
fit all demands.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the
learned should speak truth of it: here it is,
and all that belongs to't. Ask me if I am a courtier:
it shall do you no harm to learn.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: To be young again, if we could: I will be a fool
in question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. I
pray you, sir, are you a courtier?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: O Lord, sir! There's a simple putting off. More, more,
a hundred of them.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: O Lord, sir! Thick, thick, spare not me.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely meat.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: O Lord, sir! Nay, put me to't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: You were lately whipped, sir, as I think.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: O Lord, sir! spare not me.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Do you cry, âO Lord, sir!â at your whipping, and
âspare not meâ? Indeed your âO Lord, sir!â is
very sequent to your whipping: you would answer very
well to a whipping, if you were but bound to't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my âO Lord, sir!â
I see things may serve long, but not serve ever.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: I play the noble huswife with the time,
To entertain it so merrily with a fool.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O Lord, sir! why, there't serves well again.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: An end, sir; to your business. Give Helen this,
And urge her to a present answer back:
Commend me to my kinsmen and my son:
This is not much.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Not much commendation to them.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Not much employment for you: you understand me?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Most fruitfully: I am there before my legs.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Haste you again.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: They say miracles are past; and we have our
philosophical persons, to make modern and familiar,
things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it
that we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing
ourselves into seeming knowledge, when we should
submit ourselves to an unknown fear.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot
out in our latter times.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: And so 'tis.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: To be relinquished of the artists, â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: So I say, both of Galen and Paracelsus.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Of all the learned and authentic fellows, â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Right; so I say.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: That gave him out incurable, â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Why, there 'tis; so say I too.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Not to be helped, â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Right: as 'twere, a man assured of a â

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Uncertain life, and sure death.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Just, you say well; so would I have said.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: It is, indeed: if you will have it in showing, you
shall read it in â what-do-ye-call there?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: That's it; I would have said the very same.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Why, your dolphin is not lustier: 'fore me, I speak in
respect â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange, that is
the brief and the tedious of it; and he's of a
most facinerious spirit that will not acknowledge it
to be the â

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Very hand of heaven.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Ay, so I say.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: In a most weak â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: and debile minister, great power, great transcendence:
which should, indeed, give us a further use to
be made than alone the recovery of the king, as to be â
generally thankful.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I would have said it; you say well. Here comes the
king.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Lustig, as the Dutchman says: I'll like a maid
the better, whilst I have a tooth in my head: why,
he's able to lead her a coranto.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Mort du vinaigre! is not this Helen?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: 'Fore God, I think so.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go, call before me all the lords in court.
Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side;
And with this healthful hand, whose banished sense
Thou hast repealed, a second time receive
The confirmation of my promised gift,
Which but attends thy naming. Enter three or four Lords.
Fair maid, send forth thine eye: this youthful parcel
Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing,
o'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice
I have to use: thy frank election make;
Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress
Fall, when Love please marry, to each, but one!

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: I'ld give bay Curtal and his furniture,
My mouth no more were broken than these boys',
And writ as little beard.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Peruse them well:
Not one of those but had a noble father.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Heaven hath through me restored the king to health.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest,
That I protest I simply am a maid.
Please it your majesty, I have done already:
The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me,
âWe blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused,
Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever;
We'll ne'er come there again.â

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Make choice; and, see
Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly,
And to imperial Love, that god most high,
Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: And grant it.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-ace for
my life.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes,
Before I speak, too threateningly replies:
Love make your fortunes twenty times above
Her that so wishes and her humble love!

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: No better, if you please.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: My wish receive,
Which great Love grant! and so, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine,
I'd have them whipped; or I would send them to the
Turk to make eunuchs of.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Be not afraid that I your hand should take;
I'll never do you wrong for your own sake:
Blessing upon your vows! and in your bed
Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: These boys are boys of ice, they'll none have
her: sure, they are bastards to the English; the
French ne'er got 'em.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: You are too young, too happy, and too good,
To make yourself a son out of my blood.

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord
sp.l: Fair one, I think not so.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: There's one grape yet; I am sure thy father drunk
wine; but if thou be'st not an ass, I am a youth of
fourteen; I have known thee already.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I dare not say I take you; but I give
Me and my service, ever whilst I live,
Into your guiding power. This is the man.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness,
In such a business give me leave to use
The help of mine own eyes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Know'st thou not, Bertram,
What she has done for me?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Yes, my good lord;
But never hope to know why I should marry her.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou know'st she has raised me from my sickly bed.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down
Must answer for your raising? I know her well:
She had her breeding at my father's charge.
A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain
Rather corrupt me ever!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which
I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods,
Of colour, weight, and heat, poured all together,
Would quite confound distinction, yet stands off
In differences so mighty. If she be
All that is virtuous, save what thou dislikest,
A poor physician's daughter, thou dislikest
Of virtue for the name: but do not so:
From lowest place when virtuous things proceed,
The place is dignified by the doer's deed:
Where great additions swell's, and virtue none,
It is a dropsied honour. Good alone
Is good without a name. Vileness is so:
The property by what it is should go,
Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair;
In these to nature she's immediate heir,
And these breed honour: that is honour's scorn,
Which challenges itself as honour's born
And is not like the sire: honours thrive,
When rather from our acts we them derive
Than our forgoers: the mere word's a slave
Deboshed on every tomb; on every grave
A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb
Where dust and damned oblivion is the tomb
Of honoured bones indeed. What should be said?
If thou canst like this creature as a maid,
I can create the rest: virtue and she
Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do't.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: That you are well restored, my lord, I'm glad:
Let the rest go.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My honour's at the stake; which to defeat,
I must produce my power. Here, take her hand,
Proud, scornful boy, unworthy this good gift;
That dost in vile misprision shackle up
My love and her desert; that canst not dream,
We, poising us in her defective scale,
Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know,
It is in us to plant thine honour where
We please to have it grow. Check thy contempt:
Obey our will, which travails in thy good:
Believe not thy disdain, but presently
Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
Which both thy duty owes and our power claims;
Or I will throw thee from my care forever
Into the staggers and the careless lapse
Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate
Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice,
Without all terms of pity. Speak; thine answer.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit
My fancy to your eyes: when I consider
What great creation and what dole of honour
Flies where you bid it, I find that she, which late
Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now
The praised of the king; who, so ennobled,
Is as 'twere born so.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Take her by the hand,
And tell her she is thine; to whom I promise
A counterpoise, if not to thy estate
A balance more replete.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I take her hand.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Good fortune and the favour of the king
Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony
Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief,
And be performed to-night: the solemn feast
Shall more attend upon the coming space,
Expecting absent friends. As thou lovest her,
Thy love's to me religious; else, does err. Exeunt all but Lafeu and Parolles.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Do you hear, monsieur? a word with you.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Your pleasure, sir?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Your lord and master did well to make his recantation.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Recantation! My lord! my master!

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Ay; is it not a language I speak?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: A most harsh one, and not to be understood without
bloody succeeding. My master!

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Are you companion to the Count Rossillion?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: To any count, to all counts, to what is man.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: To what is count's man: count's master is of another
style.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are too
old.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man; to which title
age cannot bring thee.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a
pretty wise fellow; thou didst make tolerable
vent of thy travel; it might pass: yet the scarfs
and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly
dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too
great a burden. I have now found thee; when I
lose thee again, I care not: yet art thou good
for nothing but taking up; and that thou'rt scarce
worth.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee, â

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Do not plunge thyself too far in anger, lest thou
hasten thy trial; which if â Lord have mercy on
thee for a hen! So, my good window of lattice,
fare thee well: thy casement I need not open, for I
look through thee. Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Ay, with all my heart; and thou art worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I have not, my lord, deserved it.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Yes, good faith, every dram of it; and I will not bate
thee a scruple.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Well, I shall be wiser.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Even as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull
at a smack a' the contrary. If ever thou be'st
bound in thy scarf and beaten, thou shall find
what it is to be proud of thy bondage. I have a
desire to hold my acquaintance with thee, or
rather my knowledge, that I may say in the default, he
is a man I know.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I would it were hell-pains for thy sake, and my
poor doing eternal: for doing I am past; as I
will by thee, in what motion age will give me leave.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace
off me; scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well,
I must be patient; there is no fettering of
authority. I'll beat him, by my life, if I can
meet him with any convenience, an he were double
and double a lord. I'll have no more pity of his
age than I would have of â I'll beat him, an if I could
but meet him again.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Sirrah, your lord and master's married; there's news
for you: you have a new mistress.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to make
some reservation of your wrongs: he is my good lord:
whom I serve above is my master.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Who? God?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: The devil it is that's thy master. Why dost thou
garter up thy arms a' this fashion? dost make
hose of thy sleeves? do other servants so? Thou
wert best set thy lower part where thy nose
stands. By mine honour, if I were but two hours
younger, I'ld beat thee: methinks, thou art a
general offence, and every man should beat thee:
I think thou wast created for men to breathe
themselves upon thee.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Go to, sir; you were beaten in Italy for picking
a kernel out of a pomegranate: you are a vagabond
and no true traveller: you are more saucy with
lords and honourable personages than the commission
of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry. You
are not worth another word, else I'ld call you knave.
I leave you.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Good, very good; it is so then: good, very good; let
it be concealed awhile.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: What's the matter, sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Although before the solemn priest I have sworn,
I will not bed her.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: What, what, sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: O my Parolles, they have married me!
I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits
The tread of a man's foot: to the wars!

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: There's letters from my mother: what the import is,
I know not yet.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Ay, that would be known. To the wars, my boy, to the wars!
He wears his honour in a box unseen,
That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home,
Spending his manly marrow in her arms,
Which should sustain the bound and high curvet
Of Mars's fiery steed. To other regions
France is a stable; we that dwell in't jades;
Therefore, to the war!

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: It shall be so: I'll send her to my house,
Acquaint my mother with my hate to her,
And wherefore I am fled; write to the king
That which I durst not speak: his present gift
Shall furnish me to those Italian fields,
Where noble fellows strike: wars is no strife
To the dark house and the detested wife.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Will this capriccio hold in thee? art sure?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Go with me to my chamber and advise me.
I'll send her straight away: to-morrow
I'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it. 'Tis hard:
A young man married is a man that's marred:
Therefore away, and leave her bravely; go:
The king has done you wrong: but, hush, 'tis so. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: My mother greets me kindly: is she well?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: She is not well; but yet she has her health:
she's very merry; but yet she is not well: but
thanks be given, she's very well and wants nothing i'
the world; but yet she is not well.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: If she be very well, what does she ail that she's not
very well?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Truly, she's very well indeed, but for two things.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: What two things?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: One, that she's not in heaven, whither God send
her quickly! the other, that she's in earth, from
whence God send her quickly!

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Bless you, my fortunate lady!

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine own
good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: You had my prayers to lead them on; and to keep
them on, have them still. O, my knave, how does my old
lady?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: So that you had her wrinkles and I her money, I would
she did as you say.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Why, I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Marry, you are the wiser man; for many a man's
tongue shakes out his master's undoing: to say
nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to
have nothing, is to be a great part of your title;
which is within a very little of nothing.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Away! th' art a knave.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: You should have said, sir, before a knave th'
art a knave; that's, before me th' art a knave: this
had been truth, sir.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Go to, thou art a witty fool; I have found thee.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Did you find me in yourself, sir? or were you
taught to find me? The search, sir, was profitable;
and much fool may you find in you, even to the world's
pleasure and the increase of laughter.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: A good knave, i' faith, and well fed.
Madam, my lord will go away to-night;
A very serious business calls on him.
The great prerogative and rite of love,
Which, as your due, time claims, he does acknowledge;
But puts it off to a compelled restraint;
Whose want, and whose delay, is strewed with sweets,
Which they distill now in the curbed time,
To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy
And pleasure drown the brim.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: What's his will else?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: That you will take your instant leave a' the king,
And make this haste as your own good proceeding,
Strengthened with what apology you think
May make it probable need.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: What more commands he?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: That, having this obtained, you presently
Attend his further pleasure.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: In every thing I wait upon his will.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: I shall report it so.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I pray you. Exit Parolles. Come, sirrah. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: But I hope your lordship thinks not him a soldier.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: You have it from his own deliverance.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: And by other warranted testimony.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Then my dial goes not true: I took this lark for a
bunting.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I do assure you, my lord, he is very great in
knowledge and accordingly valiant.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I have then sinned against his experience and
transgressed against his valour; and my state
that way is dangerous, since I cannot yet find
in my heart to repent. Here he comes: I pray you, make
us friends; I will pursue the amity.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: These things shall be done, sir.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Sir?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: O, I know him well, I, sir; he, sir, 's a good
workman, a very good tailor.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Is she gone to the king?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: She is.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Will she away to-night?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: As you'll have her.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure,
Given order for our horses; and to-night,
When I should take possession of the bride,
End ere I do begin.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: A good traveller is something at the latter end
of a dinner; but one that lies three thirds and
uses a known truth to pass a thousand nothings
with, should be once heard and thrice beaten. God save
you, captain.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Is there any unkindness between my lord and you,
monsieur?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I know not how I have deserved to run into my lord's
displeasure.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: You have made shift to run into't, boots and
spurs and all, like him that leaped into the
custard; and out of it you'll run again, rather than
suffer question for your residence.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: And shall do so ever, though I took him at's
prayers. Fare you well, my lord; and believe this
of me, there can be no kernel in this light nut;
the soul of this man is his clothes. Trust him
not in matter of heavy consequence; I have kept
of them tame, and know their natures. Farewell,
monsieur: I have spoken better of you than you
have or will to deserve at my hand; but we must do
good against evil.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: An idle lord, I swear.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I think so.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Why, do you not know him?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Yes, I do know him well, and common speech
Gives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog. Enter HELENA.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I have, sir, as I was commanded from you,
Spoke with the king and have procured his leave
For present parting; only he desires
Some private speech with you.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I shall obey his will.
You must not marvel, Helen, at my course,
Which holds not colour with the time, nor does
The ministration and required office
On my particular. Prepared I was not
For such a business; therefore am I found
So much unsettled: this drives me to entreat you
That presently you take your way for home;
And rather muse than ask why I entreat you,
For my respects are better than they seem
And my appointments have in them a need
Greater than shows itself at the first view
To you that know them not. This to my mother: Giving a letter.
'Twill be two days ere I shall see you, so
I leave you to your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Sir, I can nothing say,
But that I am your most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Come, come, no more of that.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: And ever shall
With true observance seek to eke out that
Wherein toward me my homely stars have failed
To equal my great fortune.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Let that go:
My haste is very great: farewell; hie home.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Pray, sir, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Well, what would you say?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I am not worthy of the wealth I owe,
Nor dare I say 'tis mine, and yet it is;
But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal
What law does vouch mine own.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Something; and scarce so much: nothing, indeed.
I would not tell you what I would, my lord:
Faith, yes;
Strangers and foes do sunder, and not kiss.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I pray you, stay not, but in haste to horse.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I shall not break your bidding, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Where are my other men, monsieur? Farewell. Exit Helena.
Go thou toward home; where I will never come
Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum.
Away, and for our flight.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Bravely, coragio! Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter the DUKE of Florence, attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: So that from point to point now have you heard
The fundamental reasons of this war,
Whose great decision hath much blood let forth
And more thirsts after.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Holy seems the quarrel
Upon your grace's part; black and fearful
On the opposer.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Therefore we marvel much our cousin France
Would in so just a business shut his bosom
Against our borrowing prayers.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Good, my lord,
The reasons of our state I cannot yield,
But like a common and an outward man,
That the great figure of a council frames
By self-unable motion: therefore dare not
Say what I think of it, since I have found
Myself in my incertain grounds to fail
As often as I guessed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be it his pleasure.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: But I am sure the younger of our nature,
That surfeit on their ease, will day by day
Come here for physic.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Welcome shall they be;
And all the honours that can fly from us
Shall on them settle. You know your places well;
When better fall, for your avails they fell:
To-morrow to the field. Flourish. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: It hath happened all as I would have had it, save that
he comes not along with her.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: By my troth, I take my young lord to be a very
melancholy man.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: By what observance, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Why, he will look upon his boot and sing; mend
the ruff and sing; ask questions and sing; pick
his teeth and sing. I know a man that had this trick
of melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Let me see what he writes, and when he means to come.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court:
our old lings and our Isbels a' the country are
nothing like your old lings and your Isbels a'
the court: the brains of my Cupid's knocked out,
and I begin to love, as an old man loves money, with
no stomach.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: E'en that you have there.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: I have sent you a daughter-in-law: she hath
recovered the king, and undone me. I have wedded
her, not bedded her; and sworn to make the ânotâ
eternal. You shall hear I am run away: know it
before the report come. If there be breadth enough
in the world, I will hold a long distance. My duty to
you. Your unfortunate son, BERTRAM.
sp.l: This is not well, rash and unbridled boy,
To fly the favours of so good a king;
To pluck his indignation on thy head
By the misprising of a maid too virtuous
For the contempt of empire. Re-enter CLOWN.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: O madam, yonder is heavy news within between two
soldiers and my young lady!

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Nay, there is some comfort in the news, some
comfort; your son will not be killed so soon as I
thought he would.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: Why should he be killed?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: So say I, madam, if he run away, as I hear he
does: the danger is in standing to't; that's the
loss of men, though it be the getting of children.
Here they come will tell you more: for my part, I only
hear your son was run away.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Save you, good madam.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Madam, my lord is gone, for ever gone.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Do not say so.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Think upon patience. Pray you, gentlemen,
I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief,
That the first face of neither, on the start,
Can woman me unto't: where is my son, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Madam, he's gone to serve the duke of Florence:
We met him thitherward; for thence we came,
And, after some dispatch in hand at court,
Thither we bend again.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Look on his letter, madam; here's my passport.
sp.ab: When thou canst get the ring upon my finger which
never shall come off, and show me a child begotten
of thy body that I am father to, then call me
husband: but in such a âthenâ I write a ânever.â This
is a dreadful sentence.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Brought you this letter, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Ay, madam;
And for the contents' sake are sorry for our pains.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: I prithee, lady, have a better cheer;
If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine,
Thou robb'st me of a moiety: he was my son;
But I do wash his name out of my blood,
And thou art all my child. Towards Florence is he?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: And to be a soldier?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Such is his noble purpose; and, believe't,
The duke will lay upon him all the honour
That good convenience claims.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Return you thither?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: Till I have no wife I have nothing in France.
sp.l: 'Tis bitter.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Find you that there?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: 'Tis but the boldness of his hand, haply, which his
heart was not consenting to.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Nothing in France, until he have no wife!
There's nothing here that is too good for him
But only she; and she deserves a lord
That twenty such rude boys might tend upon
And call her hourly mistress. Who was with him?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: A servant only, and a gentleman
Which I have sometime known.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Parolles, was it not?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Ay, my good lady, he.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness.
My son corrupts a well-derived nature
With his inducement.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Indeed, good lady,
The fellow has a deal of that too much,
Which holds him much to have.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Y' are welcome, gentlemen.
I will entreat you, when you see my son,
To tell him that his sword can never win
The honour that he loses: more I'll entreat you
Written to bear along.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: We serve you, madam,
In that and all your worthiest affairs.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Not so, but as we change our courtesies.
Will you draw near? Exeunt Countess and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: âTill I have no wife, I have nothing in France.â
Nothing in France, until he has no wife!
Thou shalt have none, Rossillion, none in France;
Then hast thou all again. Poor lord! is't I
That chase thee from thy country and expose
Those tender limbs of thine to the event
Of the none-sparing war? and is it I
That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou
Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark
Of smoky muskets? O you leaden messengers,
That ride upon the violent speed of fire,
Fly with false aim; move the still-peering air,
That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord
Whoever shoots at him, I set him there;
Whoever charges on his forward breast,
I am the caitiff that do hold him to't;
And, though I kill him not, I am the cause
His death was so effected: better 'twere
I met the ravin lion when he roared
With sharp constraint of hunger; better 'twere
That all the miseries which nature owes
Were mine at once. No, come thou home, Rossillion,
Whence honour but of danger wins a scar,
As oft it loses all: I will be gone;
My being here it is that holds thee hence:
Shall I stay here to do't? no, no, although
The air of paradise did fan the house
And angels officed all: I will be gone,
That pitiful rumour may report my flight,
To consolate thine ear. Come, night; end, day!
For with the dark, poor thief, I'll steal away. Exit.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter the DUKE of Florence, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, Soldiers, Drum, and Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The general of our horse thou art; and we,
Great in our hope, lay our best love and credence
Upon thy promising fortune.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Sir, it is
A charge too heavy for my strength, but yet
We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake
To the extreme edge of hazard.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then go thou forth;
And fortune play upon thy prosperous helm,
As thy auspicious mistress!

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: This very day,
Great Mars, I put myself into thy file:
Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove
A lover of thy drum, hater of love. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Alas! and would you take the letter of her?
Might you not know she would do as she has done,
By sending me a letter? Read it again.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim, thither gone:
Ambitious love hath so in me offended,
That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon,
With sainted vow my faults to have amended.
Write, write, that from the bloody course of war
My dearest master, your dear son, may hie:
Bless him at home in peace, whilst I from far
His name with zealous fervour sanctify:
His taken labours bid him me forgive;
I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth
From courtly friends, with camping foes to live,
Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth:
He is too good and fair for death and me;
Whom I myself embrace, to set him free.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words!
Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much,
As letting her pass so: had I spoke with her,
I could have well diverted her intents,
Which thus she hath prevented.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: Pardon me, madam:
If I had given you this at overnight,
She might have been o'erta'en; and yet she writes,
Pursuit would be but vain.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: What angel shall
Bless this unworthy husband? he cannot thrive,
Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear
And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath
Of greatest justice. Write, write, Rinaldo,
To this unworthy husband of his wife;
Let every word weigh heavy of her worth
That he does weigh too light: my greatest grief,
Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.
Dispatch the most convenient messenger:
When haply he shall hear that she is gone,
He will return; and hope I may that she,
Hearing so much, will speed her foot again,
Led hither by pure love: which of them both
Is dearest to me, I have no skill in sense
To make distinction: provide this messenger:
My heart is heavy and mine age is weak;
Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 5
div.stage: Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.ab: Nay, come; for if they do approach the city, we shall
lose all the sight.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.ab: They say the French count has done most honourable
service.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.ab: It is reported that he has taken their greatest
commander; and that with his own hand he slew
the duke's brother.
We have lost our labour; they are gone a contrary way:
hark! you may know by their trumpets.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: Come, let's return again, and suffice ourselves
with the report of it. Well, Diana, take heed of
this French earl: the honour of a maid is her name;
and no legacy is so rich as honesty.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.ab: I have told my neighbour how you have been solicited
by a gentleman his companion.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: I know that knave; hang him! one Parolles: a
filthy officer he is in those suggestions for
the young earl. Beware of them, Diana; their
promises, enticements, oaths, tokens, and all
these engines of lust, are not the things they
go under: many a maid hath been seduced by them;
and the misery is, example, that so terrible
shows in the wrack of maidenhood, cannot for
all that dissuade succession, but that they are
limed with the twigs that threatens them. I hope
I need not to advise you further; but I hope your
own grace will keep you where you are, though
there were no further danger known but the modesty
which is so lost.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.ab: You shall not need to fear me.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.ab: I hope so.
sp.stage: Enter HELENA, disguised like a Pilgrim.
sp.ab: Look, here comes a pilgrim: I know she will lie
at my house; thither they send one another: I'll
question her. God save you, pilgrim! whither are
bound?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: To Saint Jaques le Grand.
Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: At the Saint Francis here beside the port.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Is this the way?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Ay, marry, is't. A march afar. Hark you! they come this way.
If you will tarry, holy pilgrim,
But till the troops come by,
I will conduct you where you shall be lodged;
The rather, for I think I know your hostess
As ample as myself.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Is it yourself?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: If you shall please so, pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You came, I think, from France?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I did so.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Here you shall see a countryman of yours
That has done worthy service.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: His name, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: The Count Rossillion: know you such a one?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him:
His face I know not.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Whatsome'er he is,
He's bravely taken here. He stole from France,
As 'tis reported, for the king had married him
Against his liking: think you it is so?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Ay, surely, mere the truth: I know his lady.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: There is a gentleman that serves the count
Reports but coarsely of her.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Monsieur Parolles.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: O, I believe with him,
In argument of praise, or to the worth
Of the great count himself, she is too mean
To have her name repeated: all her deserving
Is a reserved honesty, and that
I have not heard examined.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Alas, poor lady!
'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
Of a detesting lord.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I warrant, good creature, wheresoe'er she is,
Her heart weighs sadly: this young maid might do her
A shrewd turn, if she pleased.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: How do you mean?
May be the amorous count solicits her
In the unlawful purpose.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: He does indeed;
And brokes with all that can in such a suit
Corrupt the tender honour of a maid:
But she is armed for him and keeps her guard
In honestest defence.

sp.speaker: Mariana
