sp.l: The gods forbid else!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: So, now they come: Drum and Colours. Enter BERTRAM, PAROLLES, and the whole army.
That is Antonio, the duke's eldest son;
That, Escalus.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Which is the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: He;
That with the plume: 'tis a most gallant fellow.
I would he loved his wife: if he were honester
He were much goodlier: is't not a handsome gentleman?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: I like him well.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: 'Tis pity he is not honest: yond's that same knave
That leads him to these places: were I his lady,
I would poison that vile rascal.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Which is he?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.ab: That jackanapes with scarfs: why is he melancholy?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.ab: Perchance he's hurt i' the battle.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Lose our drum! well.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: He's shrewdly vexed at something: look, he has spied
us.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.ab: Marry, hang you!

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: The troop is past. Come, pilgrim, I will bring you
Where you shall host: of enjoined penitents
There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound,
Already at my house.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I humbly thank you:
Please it this matron and this gentle maid
To eat with us to-night, the charge and thanking
Shall be for me; and, to requite you further,
I will bestow some precepts of this virgin
Worthy the note.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: We'll take your offer kindly. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 6
div.stage: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Nay, good my lord, put him to't; let him have his way.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: If your lordship find him not a hilding, hold me no
more in your respect.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: On my life, my lord, a bubble.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Do you think I am so far deceived in him?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge,
without any malice, but to speak of him as my
kinsman, he's a most notable coward, an infinite
and endless liar, an hourly promise-breaker, the
owner of no one good quality worthy your lordship's
entertainment.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing too far
in his virtue, which he hath not, he might at
some great and trusty business in a main danger fail
you.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: None better than to let him fetch off his drum, which
you hear him so confidently undertake to do.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I, with a troop of Florentines, will suddenly
surprise him; such I will have, whom I am sure
he knows not from the enemy: we will bind and
hoodwink him so, that he shall suppose no other
but that he is carried into the leaguer of the
adversaries, when we bring him to our own tents.
Be but your lordship present at his examination:
if he do not, for the promise of his life and in
the highest compulsion of base fear, offer to
betray you and deliver all the intelligence in
his power against you, and that with the divine
forfeit of his soul upon oath, never trust my
judgement in any thing.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his
drum; he says he has a stratagem for't: when your
lordship sees the bottom of his success in't,
and to what metal this counterfeit lump of ore
will be melted, if you give him not John Drum's
entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed. Here
he comes.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: O, for the love of laughter, hinder not the honour
of his design: let him fetch off his drum in any hand.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: How now, monsieur! this drum sticks sorely in your
disposition.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: A pox on't, let it go; 'tis but a drum.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: âBut a drumâ! is't âbut a drumâ? A drum so lost!
There was excellent command, â to charge in with
our horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own
soldiers!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: That was not to be blamed in the command of the
service: it was a disaster of war that Caesar
himself could not have prevented, if he had been there
to command.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success: some
dishonour we had in the loss of that drum; but it is
not to be recovered.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: It might have been recovered.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: It might; but it is not now.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: It is to be recovered: but that the merit of
service is seldom attributed to the true and
exact performer, I would have that drum or another, or
âhic jacet.â

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur: if
you think your mystery in stratagem can bring
this instrument of honour again into his native
quarter, be magnanimous in the enterprise and go
on; I will grace the attempt for a worthy exploit:
if you speed well in it, the duke shall both
speak of it, and extend to you what further
becomes his greatness, even to the utmost syllable of
your worthiness.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: But you must not now slumber in it.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I'll about it this evening: and I will presently
pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my
certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation; and
by midnight look to hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are gone about
it?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I know not what the success will be, my lord; but the
attempt I vow.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I know th' art valiant: and, to the possibility
of thy soldiership, will subscribe for thee. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I love not many words.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a
strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently
seems to undertake this business, which he knows
is not to be done; damns himself to do and dares
better be damned than to do't?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: You do not know him, my lord, as we do: certain
it is, that he will steal himself into a man's
favour and for a week escape a great deal of
discoveries; but when you find him out, you have him
ever after.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of this
that so seriously he does address himself unto?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: None in the world; but return with an invention
and clap upon you two or three probable lies:
but we have almost embossed him: you shall see
his fall to-night; for indeed he is not for your
lordship's respect.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we
case him. He was first smoked by the old lord
Lafeu: when his disguise and he is parted, tell
me what a sprat you shall find him; which you shall
see this very night.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: I must go look my twigs: he shall be caught.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Your brother he shall go along with me.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: As't please your lordship; I'll leave you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Now will I lead you to the house, and show you
The lass I spoke of.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: But you say she's honest.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: That's all the fault: I spoke with her but once
And found her wondrous cold; but I sent to her,
By this same coxcomb that we have i' the wind,
Tokens and letters which she did re-send;
And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature:
Will you go see her?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: With all my heart, my lord. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: If you misdoubt me that I am not she,
I know not how I shall assure you further,
But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Though my estate be fallen, I was well born,
Nothing acquainted with these businesses;
And would not put my reputation now
In any staining act.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Nor would I wish you.
First, give me trust, the count he is my husband,
And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken
Is so from word to word; and then you cannot,
By the good aid that I of you shall borrow,
Err in bestowing it.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I should believe you;
For you have showed me that which well approves
Y' are great in fortune,

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Take this purse of gold,
And let me buy your friendly help thus far,
Which I will overpay and pay again
When I have found it. The count he woos your daughter,
Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,
Resolved to carry her: let her in fine consent,
As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it.
Now his important blood will nought deny
That she'll demand: a ring the county wears,
That downward hath succeeded in his house
From son to son, some four or five descents
Since the first father wore it: this ring he holds
In most rich choice; yet in his idle fire,
To buy his will, it would not seem too dear,
Howe'er repented after.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Now I see
The bottom of your purpose.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: You see it lawful, then: it is no more,
But that your daughter, ere she seems as won,
Desires this ring; appoints him an encounter;
In fine, delivers me to fill the time,
Herself most chastely absent: after,
To marry her, I'll add three thousand crowns
To what is past already.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I have yielded:
Instruct my daughter how she shall persever,
That time and place with this deceit so lawful
May prove coherent. Every night he comes
With musics of all sorts and songs composed
To her unworthiness: it nothing steads us
To chide him from our eaves; for he persists
As if his life lay on't.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Why then to-night
Let us assay our plot; which, if it speed,
Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed
And lawful meaning in a lawful act,
Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact:
But let's about it. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner.
When you sally upon him, speak what terrible
language you will: though you understand it not
yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to
understand him, unless some one among us whom we must
produce for an interpreter.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: No, sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us
again?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: E'en such as you speak to me.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: He must think us some band of strangers i' the
adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack
of all neighbouring languages; therefore we must
every one be a man of his own fancy, not to know
what we speak one to another; so we seem to know,
is to know straight our purpose: choughs' language,
gabble enough, and good enough. As for you,
interpreter, you must seem very politic. But
couch, ho! here he comes, to beguile two hours
in a sleep, and then to return and swear the lies he
forges.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Ten o'clock: within these three hours 'twill be
time enough to go home. What shall I say I have
done? It must be a very plausive invention that
carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces
have of late knocked too often at my door. I find
my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath
the fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not
daring the reports of my tongue.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was
guilty of.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: What the devil should move me to undertake the
recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the
impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose?
I must give myself some hurts, and say I got them
in exploit: yet slight ones will not carry it;
they will say, âCame you off with so little?â
and great ones I dare not give. Wherefore, what's
the instance? Tongue, I must put you into a
butter-woman's mouth and buy myself another of
Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be that
he is?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the
turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: We cannot afford you so.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in
stratagem.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: 'Twould not do.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Hardly serve.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the
citadel â

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: How deep?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Thirty fathom.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I would I had any drum of the enemy's: I would swear I
recovered it.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: You shall hear one anon.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: A drum now of the enemy's, â

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes. They seize and blindfold him.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: I know you are the Muskos' regiment:
And I shall lose my life for want of language:
If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him speak to me; I'll
Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Boskos vauvado; I understand thee, and can speak
thy tongue. Kerelybonto, sir, betake thee to thy
faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: O!

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: The general is content to spare thee yet;
And, hoodwinked as thou art, will lead thee on
To gather from thee: haply thou mayst inform
Something to save thy life.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: O, let me live!
And all the secrets of our camp I'll show,
Their force, their purposes; nay, I'll speak that
Which you will wonder at.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: But wilt thou faithfully?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: If I do not, damn me.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Acordo linta. Come on; thou art granted space. Exit, with Parolles guarded. A short alarum within.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Go, tell the Count Rossillion, and my brother,
We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled
Till we do hear from them.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Captain, I will.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: 'A will betray us all unto ourselves:
Inform on that.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: So I will, sir.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Till then I'll keep him dark and safely locked. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: No, my good lord, Diana.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Titled goddess;
And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul,
In your fine frame hath love no quality?
If the quick fire of youth light not your mind,
You are no maiden, but a monument:
When you are dead, you should be such a one
As you are now, for you are cold and stern;
And now you should be as your mother was
When your sweet self was got.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: She then was honest.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: So should you be.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: No:
My mother did but duty; such, my lord,
As you owe to your wife.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: No more a' that;
I prithee, do not strive against my vows:
I was compelled to her; but I love thee
By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever
Do thee all rights of service.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Ay, so you serve us
Till we serve you; but when you have our roses,
You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves
And mock us with our bareness.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: How have I sworn!

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,
But the plain single vow that is vowed true.
What is not holy, that we swear not by,
But take the High'st to witness: then, pray you, tell me,
If I should swear by Jove's great attributes,
I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths,
When I did love you ill? This has no holding,
To swear by him whom I protest to love,
That I will work against him: therefore your oaths
Are words and poor conditions, but unsealed,
At least in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Change it, change it;
Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy;
And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts
That you do charge men with. Stand no more off,
But give thyself unto my sick desires,
Who then recovers: say thou art mine, and ever
My love as it begins shall so persever.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I see that men make rope's in such a scarre
That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I'll lend it thee, my dear; but have no power
To give it from me.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Will you not, my lord?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: It is an honour 'longing to our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Mine honour's such a ring:
My chastity's the jewel of our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom
Brings in the champion Honour on my part,
Against your vain assault.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Here, take my ring:
My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine,
And I'll be bid by thee.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window:
I'll order take my mother shall not hear.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
When you have conquered my yet maiden bed,
Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:
My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them
When back again this ring shall be delivered:
And on your finger in the night I'll put
Another ring, that what in time proceeds
May token to the future our past deeds.
Adieu, till then; then, fail not. You have won
A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: For which live long to thank both heaven and me!
You may so in the end.
My mother told me just how he would woo,
As if she sat in's heart; she says all men
Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me
When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,
Marry that will, I live and die a maid:
Only in this disguise I think't no sin
To cozen him that would unjustly win. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: You have not given him his mother's letter?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I have delivered it an hour since: there is
something in't that stings his nature; for on
the reading it he changed almost into another man.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking off
so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Especially he hath incurred the everlasting
displeasure of the king, who had even tuned his
bounty to sing happiness to him I will tell you
a thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the grave
of it.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in
Florence, of a most chaste renown; and this night
he fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour:
he hath given her his monumental ring, and thinks
himself made in the unchaste composition.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Now, God delay our rebellion! as we are ourselves.
what things are we!

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Merely our own traitors. And as in the common
course of all treasons, we still see them reveal
themselves, till they attain to their abhorred
ends, so he that in this action contrives against
his own nobility, in his proper stream o'erflows
himself.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Is it not meant damnable in us, to be trumpeters
of our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his
company to-night?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: That approaches apace; I would gladly have him
see his company anatomized, that he might take
a measure of his own judgements, wherein so curiously
he had set this counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his
presence must be the whip of the other.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: In the meantime, what hear you of these wars?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I hear there is an overture of peace.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: What will Count Rossillion do then? will he travel
higher, or return again into France?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether of
his council.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Let it be forbid, sir; so should I be a great deal of
his act.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from
his house: her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint
Jaques le Grand; which holy undertaking with most
austere sanctimony she accomplished; and, there
residing, the tenderness of her nature became as
a prey to her grief; in fine, made a groan of her last
breath, and now she sings in heaven.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: How is this justified?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which
makes her story true, even to the point of her
death: her death itself, which could not be her
office to say is come, was faithfully confirmed by the
rector of the place.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Hath the count all this intelligence?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from
point, to the full arming of the verity.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our
losses!

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: And how mightily some other times we drown our
gain in tears! The great dignity that his valour
hath here acquired for him shall at home be
encountered with a shame as ample.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good
and ill together: our virtues would be proud, if
our faults whipped them not; and our crimes would
despair, if they were not cherished by our virtues.
How now! where's your master?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: He met the duke in the street, sir, of whom he
hath taken a solemn leave: his lordship will next
morning for France. The duke hath offered him letters
of commendations to the king.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: They shall be no more than needful there, if they were
more than they can commend.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: They cannot be too sweet for the king's tartness.
Here's his lordship now.
How now, my lord! is't not after midnight?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I have to-night dispatched sixteen businesses a
month's length a-piece, by an abstract of success:
I have congied with the duke, done my adieu with
his nearest; buried a wife, mourned for her; writ
to my lady mother I am returning; entertained my
convoy; and between these main parcels of dispatch
effected many nicer needs: the last was the greatest,
but that I have not ended yet.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: If the business be of any difficulty, and this
morning your departure hence, it requires haste of
your lordship.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I mean, the business is not ended, as fearing to
hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this
dialogue between the fool and the soldier? Come,
bring forth this counterfeit module, he's deceived me,
like a double-meaning prophesier.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Bring him forth: he's sat i' the stocks all night,
poor gallant knave.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: No matter; his heels have deserved it, in usurping his
spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I have told your lordship already the stocks
carry him. But to answer you as you would be
understood; he weeps like a wench that had shed
her milk: he hath confessed himself to Morgan,
whom he supposes to be a friar, from the time of
his remembrance to this very instant disaster of
his setting i' the stocks: and what think you he hath
confessed?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Nothing of me, has 'a?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to
his face: if your lordship be in't, as I believe you
are, you must have the patience to hear it,
sp.stage: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing of me:

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Hush, hush! Hoodman comes! Portotartarosa.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: He calls for the tortures: what will you say without
'em?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I will confess what I know without constraint: if ye
pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Bosko chimurcho.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: You are a merciful general. Our general bids you
answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: And truly, as I hope to live.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: âFirst demand of him how many horse the duke is
strong.â What say you to that?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Five or six thousand; but very weak and unserviceable:
the troops are all scattered, and the commanders
very poor rogues, upon my reputation and credit and as
I hope to live.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Shall I set down your answer so?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Do: I'll take the sacrament on't, how and which way
you will.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Y' are deceived, my lord: this is Monsieur
Parolles, the gallant militarist, â that was his
own phrase, â that had the whole theoric of war
in the knot of his scarf, and the practice in the
chape of his dagger.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I will never trust a man again for keeping his
sword clean, nor believe he can have every thing in
him by wearing his apparel neatly.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Well, that's set down.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Five or six thousand horse, I said, â I will say
true, â or thereabouts, set down, for I'll speak truth.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: He's very near the truth in this.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: But I con him no thanks for't, in the nature he
delivers it.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Poor rogues, I pray you, say.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Well, that's set down.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I humbly thank you, sir: a truth's a truth, the rogues
are marvellous poor.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: âDemand of him, of what strength they are afoot.â What
say you to that?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present
hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a
hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus,
so many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo,
Lodowick, and Gratii, two hundred fifty each;
mine own company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii,
two hundred fifty each; so that the muster-file,
rotten and sound, upon my life, amounts not to
fifteen thousand poll; half of the which dare
not shake the snow from off their cassocks, lest they
shake themselves to pieces.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: What shall be done to him?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him
my condition, and what credit I have with the duke.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Well, that's set down.
âYou shall demand of him, whether one Captain
Dumain be i' the camp, a Frenchman; what his
reputation is with the duke; what his valour,
honesty, and expertness in wars; or whether he
thinks it were not possible, with well-weighing
sums of gold, to corrupt him to a revolt.â What say
you to this? what do you know of it?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of the
inter'gatories: demand them singly.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Do you know this Captain Dumain?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I know him: 'a was a botcher's 'prentice in Paris,
from whence he was whipped for getting the
shrieve's fool with child, â a dumb innocent, that could
not say him nay.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I
know his brains are forfeit to the next tile that
falls.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Well, is this captain in the duke of Florence's camp?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Nay, look not so upon me; we shall hear of your
lordship anon.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: What is his reputation with the duke?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: The duke knows him for no other but a poor officer
of mine; and writ to me this other day to turn
him out a' the band: I think I have his letter in my
pocket.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Marry, we'll search.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: In good sadness, I do not know; either it is
there, or it is upon a file with the duke's other
letters in my tent.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Here 'tis; here's a paper: shall I read it to you?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I do not know if it be it or no.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Our interpreter does it well.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Excellently.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: âDian, the count's a fool, and full of gold,â â

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: That is not the duke's letter, sir; that is an
advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one
Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one
Count Rossillion, a foolish idle boy, but for
all that very ruttish: I pray you, sir, put it up
again.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: Nay, I'll read it first, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in
the behalf of the maid; for I knew the young
count to be a dangerous and lascivious boy, who
is a whale to virginity and devours up all the fry it
finds.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Damnable both-sides rogue!

sp.speaker: First Soldier

lg.l: âWhen he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it;
After he scores, he never pays the score:
Half won is match well made; match, and well make it;
He ne'er pays after-debts, take it before;
And say a soldier, Dian, told thee this,
Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss:
For count of this, the count's a fool, I know it,
Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.

sp.ab: Thine, as he vowed to thee in thine ear, PAROLLES.â

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: He shall be whipped through the army with this rhyme
in's forehead.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold
linguist and the armipotent soldier.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: I could endure any thing before but a cat, and now
he's a cat to me.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: I perceive, sir, by the general's looks, we shall be
fain to hang you.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: My life, sir, in any case: not that I am afraid
to die; but that, my offences being many, I would
repent out the remainder of nature: let me live,
sir, in a dungeon, i' the stocks, or any where, so I
may live.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely;
therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you
have answered to his reputation with the duke and to
his valour: what is his honesty?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister:
for rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus:
he professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking
'em he is stronger than Hercules: he will lie,
sir, with such volubility, that you would think
truth were a fool; drunkenness is his best virtue,
for he will be swine-drunk; and in his sleep he
does little harm, save to his bed-clothes about
him; but they know his conditions and lay him in
straw. I have but little more to say, sir, of
his honesty: he has every thing that an honest
man should not have; what an honest man should have,
he has nothing.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: I begin to love him for this.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon him
for me, he's more and more a cat.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: What say you to his expertness in war?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Faith, sir, he's led the drum before the English
tragedians; to belie him, I will not, and more
of his soldiership I know not; except, in that
country he had the honour to be the officer at
a place there called Mile-end, to instruct for
the doubling of files: I would do the man what honour
I can, but of this I am not certain.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: He hath outvillained villainy so far, that the rarity
redeems him.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: A pox on him, he's a cat still.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: His qualities being at this poor price, I need not to
ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Sir, for a cardecu he will sell the fee-simple
of his salvation, the inheritance of it; and cut
the entail from all remainders, and a perpetual
succession for it perpetually.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Why does he ask him of me?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: What's he?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: E'en a crow a' the same nest; not altogether so
great as the first in goodness, but greater a
great deal in evil: he excels his brother for a
coward, yet his brother is reputed one of the
best that is: in a retreat he outruns any lackey;
marry, in coming on he has the cramp.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray
the Florentine?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rossillion.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: I'll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I'll no more drumming; a plague of all drums!
Only to seem to deserve well, and to beguile the
supposition of that lascivious young boy the
count, have I run into this danger. Yet who would have
suspected an ambush where I was taken?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die: the
general says, you that have so traitorously
discovered the secrets of your army and made such
pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can
serve the world for no honest use; therefore you must
die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: That shall you, and take your leave of all your
friends.
So, look about you: know you any here?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.ab: Good morrow, noble captain.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: God save you, noble captain.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu? I am
for France.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the
sonnet you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count
Rossillion? an I were not a very coward, I'ld compel
it of you: but fare you well.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; that has
a knot on't yet.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.ab: If you could find out a country where but women
were that had received so much shame, you might
begin an impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir; I am for
France too: we shall speak of you there.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.l: Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great,
'Twould burst at this. Captain I'll be no more;
But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft
As captain shall: simply the thing I am
Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart,
Let him fear this, for it will come to pass
That every braggart shall be found an ass.
Rust, sword! cool, blushes! and, Parolles, live
Safest in shame! being fooled, by foolery thrive!
There's place and means for every man alive.
I'll after them. Exit.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: That you may well perceive I have not wronged you,
One of the greatest in the Christian world
Shall be my surety; 'fore whose throne 'tis needful,
Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel:
Time was, I did him a desired office,
Dear almost as his life; which gratitude
Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth,
And answer, thanks: I duly am informed
His grace is at Marseilles; to which place
We have convenient convoy. You must know,
I am supposed dead: the army breaking,
My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding,
And by the leave of my good lord the king,
We'll be before our welcome.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Gentle madam,
You never had a servant to whose trust
Your business was more welcome.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Nor you, mistress,
Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour
To recompense your love: doubt not but heaven
Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motive
And helper to a husband. But, O strange men!
That can such sweet use make of what they hate,
When saucy trusting of the cozened thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night: so lust doth play
With what it loathes for that which is away.
But more of this hereafter. You, Diana,
Under my poor instructions yet must suffer
Something in my behalf.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Let death and honesty
Go with your impositions, I am yours
Upon your will to suffer.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Yet, I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on summer,
When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns,
And be as sweet as sharp. We must away;
Our waggon is prepared, and time revives us:
ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL: still the fine's the crown;
What e'er the course, the end is the renown. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta
fellow there, whose villainous saffron would have
made all the unbaked and doughy youth of a nation
in his colour: your daughter-in-law had been
alive at this hour, and your son here at home,
more advanced by the king than by that red-tailed
humble-bee I speak of.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: I would I had not known him; it was the death of
the most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature
had praise for creating. If she had partaken of
my flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a mother,
I could not have owed her a more rooted love.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: 'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady: we may pick
a thousand sallets ere we light on such another herb.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of the salad,
or rather, the herb of grace.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: They are not herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not much
skill in grass.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Whether dost thou profess thyself, a knave or a fool?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a
man's.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Your distinction?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: So you were a knave at his service, indeed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her
service.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and
fool.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: At your service.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as great
a prince as you are.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Who's that? a Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Faith, sir, 'a has an English name; but his fisnomy is
more hotter in France than there.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: What prince is that?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: The black prince, sir; alias, the prince of darkness;
alias, the devil.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Hold thee, there's my purse; I give thee not this
to suggest thee from thy master thou talkest of; serve
him still.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved
a great fire; and the master I speak of ever
keeps a good fire. But, sure, he is the prince
of the world; let his nobility remain in's court.
I am for the house with the narrow gate, which
I take to be too little for pomp to enter: some
that humble themselves may; but the many will be
too chill and tender, and they'll be for the
flowery way that leads to the broad gate and the great
fire.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee; and
I tell thee so before, because I would not fall
out with thee. Go thy ways: let my horses be well
looked to, without any tricks.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall be
jades' tricks; which are their own right by the law of
nature.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: So 'a is. My lord that's gone made himself much
sport out of him: by his authority he remains
here, which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness;
and, indeed, he has no pace, but runs where he will.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I like him well; 'tis not amiss. And I was about
to tell you, since I heard of the good lady's
death and that my lord your son was upon his
return home, I moved the king my master to speak
in the behalf of my daughter; which, in the
minority of them both, his majesty, out of a
self-gracious remembrance, did first propose:
his highness hath promised me to do it: and, to
stop up the displeasure he hath conceived against
your son, there is no fitter matter. How does your
ladyship like it?

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: With very much content, my lord; and I wish it happily
effected.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: His highness comes post from Marseilles, of as
able body as when he numbered thirty: 'a will be
here to-morrow, or I am deceived by him that in such
intelligence hath seldom failed.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere
I die. I have letters that my son will be here
to-night: I shall beseech your lordship to remain with
me till they meet together.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might safely
be admitted.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.ab: You need but plead your honourable privilege.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but I thank
my God it holds yet.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch
of velvet on's face: whether there be a scar
under't or no, the velvet knows; but 'tis a goodly
patch of velvet: his left cheek is a cheek of
two pile and a half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good livery of
honour; so belike is that.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: But it is your carbonadoed face.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Let us go see your son, I pray you: I long to talk
with the young noble soldier.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Faith, there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine
hats and most courteous feathers, which bow the head
and nod at every man.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: But this exceeding posting day and night
Must wear your spirits low; we cannot help it:
But since you have made the days and nights as one,
To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs,
Be bold you do so grow in my requital
As nothing can unroot you. In happy time; Enter a Gentleman.
This man may help me to his majesty's ear,
If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: And you.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: I have been sometimes there.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I do presume, sir, that you are not fallen
From the report that goes upon your goodness;
And therefore, goaded with most sharp occasions,
Which lay nice manners by, I put you to
The use of your own virtues, for the which
I shall continue thankful.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: What's your will?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: That it will please you
To give this poor petition to the king,
And aid me with that store of power you have
To come into his presence.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: The king's not here.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: Not here, sir!

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Not, indeed:
He hence removed last night and with more haste
Than is his use.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Lord, how we lose our pains!

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL yet,
Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.
I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Marry, as I take it, to Rossillion;
Whither I am going.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: I do beseech you, sir,
Since you are like to see the king before me,
Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
Which I presume shall render you no blame
But rather make you thank your pains for it.
I will come after you with what good speed
Our means will make us means.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: This I'll do for you.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: And you shall find yourself to be well thanked,
What e'er falls more. We must to horse again.
Go, go, provide. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Good Master Lavache, give my Lord Lafeu this
letter: I have ere now, sir, been better known
to you, when I have held familiarity with fresher
clothes; but I am now, sir, muddied in fortune's
mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong
displeasure.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Truly, fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if
it smell so strongly as thou speakest of: I will
henceforth eat no fish of fortune's buttering.
Prithee, allow the wind.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir; I spake but
by a metaphor.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop
my nose; or against any man's metaphor. Prithee, get
thee further.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: Foh! prithee, stand away: a paper from fortune's
close-stool to give to a nobleman! Look, here he
comes himself.
Here is a purr of fortune's, sir, or of fortune's
cat, â but not a musk-cat, â that has fallen into
the unclean fishpond of her displeasure, and, as
he says, is muddied withal: pray you, sir, use
the carp as you may; for he looks like a poor,
decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I
do pity his distress in my similes of comfort and
leave him to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: My lord, I am a man whom fortune hath cruelly
scratched.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: And what would you have me to do? 'Tis too late
to pare her nails now. Wherein have you played
the knave with fortune, that she should scratch
you, who of herself is a good lady and would not
have knaves thrive long under her? There's a
cardecu for you: let the justices make you and fortune
friends: I am for other business.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: You beg a single penny more: come, you shall ha't;
save your word.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: My name, my good lord; is Parolles.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: You beg more than âword,â then. Cox my passion! give
me your hand. How does your drum?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: O my good lord, you were the first that found me!

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Was I, in sooth? and I was the first that lost thee.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace,
for you did bring me out.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Out upon thee, knave! dost thou put upon me at
once both the office of God and the devil? One
brings thee in grace and the other brings thee
out.
The king's coming; I know by his trumpets. Sirrah,
inquire further after me; I had talk of you last
night: though you are a fool and a knave, you shall
eat; go to, follow.

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I praise God for you.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We lost a jewel of her; and our esteem
Was made much poorer by it: but your son,
As mad in folly, lacked the sense to know
Her estimation home.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: 'Tis past, my liege;
And I beseech your majesty to make it
Natural rebellion, done i' the blade of youth;
When oil and fire, too strong for reason's force,
o'erbears it and burns on.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My honoured lady,
I have forgiven and forgotten all;
Though my revenges were high bent upon him,
And watched the time to shoot.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: This I must say,
But first I beg my pardon, the young lord
Did to his majesty, his mother and his lady
Offence of mighty note; but to himself
The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife
Whose beauty did astonish the survey
Of richest eyes, whose words all ears took captive,
Whose dear perfection hearts that scorned to serve
Humbly called mistress.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Praising what is lost
Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither;
We are reconciled, and the first view shall kill
All repetition: let him not ask our pardon;
The nature of his great offence is dead,
And deeper than oblivion we do bury
The incensing relics of it: let him approach,
A stranger, no offender; and inform him
So 'tis our will he should.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: I shall, my liege. Exit.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What says he to your daughter? have you spoke?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: All that he is hath reference to your highness.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me
That sets him high in fame. Enter BERTRAM.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: He looks well on't.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am not a day of season,
For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail
In me at once: but to the brightest beams
Distracted clouds give way; so stand thou forth;
The time is fair again.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: My high-repented blames,
Dear sovereign, pardon to me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: All is whole;
Not one word more of the consumed time.
Let's take the instant by the forward top;
For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees
The inaudible and noiseless foot of Time
Steals ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this lord?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Admiringly, my liege, at first
I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart
Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue:
Where the impression of mine eye infixing,
Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me,
Which warped the line of every other favour;
Scorned a fair colour, or expressed it stolen;
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a most hideous object: thence it came
That she whom all men praised and whom myself,
Since I have lost, have loved, was in mine eye
The dust that did offend it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Well excused:
That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away
From the great compt: but love that comes too late,
Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried,
To the great sender turns a sour offence,
Crying, âThat's good that's gone.â Our rash faults
Make trivial price of serious things we have,
Not knowing them until we know their grave:
Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust,
Destroy our friends and after weep their dust:
Our own love waking cries to see what's done,
While shameful hate sleeps out the afternoon.
Be this sweet Helen's knell, and now forget her.
Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin:
The main consents are had; and here we'll stay
To see our widower's second marriage-day.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless!
Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: Come on, my son, in whom my house's name
Must be digested, give a favour from you
To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter,
That she may quickly come. Bertram gives a ring. By my old beard,
And every hair that's on't, Helen, that's dead,
Was a sweet creature: such a ring as this,
The last that e'er I took her leave at court,
I saw upon her finger.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Hers it was not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now, pray you, let me see it; for mine eye,
While I was speaking, oft was fastened to't.
This ring was mine; and, when I gave it Helen,
I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood
Necessitied to help, that by this token
I would relieve her. Had you that craft, to reave her
Of what should stead her most?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: My gracious sovereign,
Howe'er it pleases you to take it so,
The ring was never hers.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Son, on my life,
I have seen her wear it; and she reckoned it
At her life's rate.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: I am sure I saw her wear it.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: You are deceived, my lord; she never saw it:
In Florence was it from a casement thrown me,
Wrapped in a paper, which contained the name
Of her that threw it: noble she was, and thought
I stood engaged: but when I had subscribed
To mine own fortune and informed her fully
I could not answer in that course of honour
As she had made the overture, she ceased.
In heavy satisfaction and would never
Receive the ring again.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Plutus himself,
That knows the tinct and multiplying medicine,
Hath not in nature's mystery more science
Than I have in this ring: 'twas mine, 'twas Helen's,
Whoever gave it you. Then, if you know
That you are well acquainted with yourself,
Confess 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement
You got it from her: she called the saints to surety
That she would never put it from her finger,
Unless she gave it to yourself in bed,
Where you have never come, or sent it us
Upon her great disaster.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: She never saw it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou speak'st it falsely, as I love mine honour;
And makest conjectural fears to come into me
Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove
That thou art so inhuman, â 'twill not prove so; â
And yet I know not: thou didst hate her deadly,
And she is dead; which nothing, but to close
Her eyes myself, could win me to believe,
More than to see this ring. Take him away. Guards seize Bertram.
My fore-past proofs, howe'er the matter fall,
Shall tax my fears of little vanity,
Having vainly feared too little. Away with him!
We'll sift this matter further.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: If you shall prove
This ring was ever hers, you shall as easy
Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet she never was. Exit guarded,.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am wrapped in dismal thinkings. Enter a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Gracious sovereign,
Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not:
Here's a petition from a Florentine,
Who hath for four or five removes come short
To tender it herself. I undertook it,
Vanquished thereto by the fair grace and speech
Of the poor suppliant, who by this I know
Is here attending: her business looks in her
With an importing visage; and she told me,
In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern
Your highness with herself.

sp.speaker: King
sp.ab: Upon his many protestations to marry me when his
wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now
is the Count Rossillion a widower: his vows are
forfeited to me, and my honour's paid to him. He
stole from Florence, taking no leave, and I follow
him to his country for justice: grant it me, O
king! in you it best lies; otherwise a seducer
flourishes, and a poor maid is undone. DIANA CAPILET.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll for
this: I'll none of him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The heavens have thought well on thee, Lafeu,
To bring forth this discovery. Seek these suitors:
Go speedily and bring again the count.
I am afeard the life of Helen, lady,
Was foully snatched.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: Now, justice on the doers! Re-enter BERTRAM, guarded.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you,
And that you fly them as you swear them lordship,
Yet you desire to marry. Enter Widow and DIANA. What woman's that?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine,
Derived from the ancient Capilet:
My suit, as I do understand, you know,
And therefore know how far I may be pitied.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I am her mother, sir, whose age and honour
Both suffer under this complaint we bring,
And both shall cease, without your remedy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come hither, count; do you know these women?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: My lord, I neither can nor will deny
But that I know them: do they charge me further?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Why do you look so strange upon your wife?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: She's none of mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: If you shall marry,
You give away this hand, and that is mine;
You give away heaven's vows, and those are mine;
You give away myself, which is known mine;
For I by vow am so embodied yours,
That she which marries you must marry me,
Either both or none.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Your reputation comes too short for my daughter; you
are no husband for her.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: My lord, this is a fond and desperate creature,
Whom sometime I have laughed with: let your highness
Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour
Than for to think that I would sink it here.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend
Till your deeds gain them: fairer prove your honour
Than in my thought it lies.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Good, my lord,
Ask him upon his oath, if he does think
He had not my virginity.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What say'st thou to her?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: She's impudent, my lord,
And was a common gamester to the camp.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: He does me wrong, my lord; if I were so,
He might have bought me at a common price:
Do not believe him. O, behold this ring,
Whose high respect and rich validity
Did lack a parallel; yet for all that
He gave it to a commoner a' the camp,
If I be one.

sp.speaker: Countess
sp.l: He blushes, and 'tis hit:
Of six preceding ancestors, that gem,
Conferred by testament to the sequent issue,
Hath it been owed and worn. This is his wife;
That ring's a thousand proofs.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Methought you said
You saw one here in court could witness it.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I did, my lord, but loath am to produce
So bad an instrument: his name's Parolles.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.l: I saw the man to-day, if man he be.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Find him, and bring him hither. Exit an Attendant.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: What of him?
He's quoted for a most perfidious slave,
With all the spots a' the world taxed and deboshed;
Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth.
Am I or that or this for what he'll utter,
That will speak any thing?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: She hath that ring of yours.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I think she has: certain it is I liked her,
And boarded her i' the wanton way of youth:
She knew her distance and did angle for me,
Madding my eagerness with her restraint,
As all impediments in fancy's course
Are motives of more fancy; and, in fine,
Her infinite cunning, with her modern grace,
Subdued me to her rate: she got the ring;
And I had that which any inferior might
At market-price have bought.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I must be patient.
You, that have turned off a first so noble wife,
May justly diet me. I pray you yet;
Since you lack virtue, I will lose a husband;
Send for your ring, I will return it home,
And give me mine again.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: I have it not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What ring was yours, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Sir, much like
The same upon your finger.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Know you this ring? this ring was his of late.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: And this was it I gave him, being a-bed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The story then goes false, you threw it him
Out of a casement.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I have spoke the truth. Enter PAROLLES.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You boggle shrewdly, every feather starts you.
Is this the man you speak of?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Tell me, sirrah, but tell me true, I charge you,
Not fearing the displeasure of your master,
Which on your just proceeding I'll keep off,
By him and by this woman here what know you?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: So please your majesty, my master hath been an
honourable gentleman: tricks he hath had in him, which
gentlemen have.

sp.speaker: King
sp.ab: Come, come, to the purpose: did he love this woman?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Faith, sir, he did love her; but how?

sp.speaker: King
sp.ab: How, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.

sp.speaker: King
sp.ab: How is that?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: He loved her, sir, and loved her not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.ab: As thou art a knave, and no knave. What an equivocal
companion is this!

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: I am a poor man, and at your majesty's command.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: He's a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.ab: Do you know he promised me marriage?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Faith, I know more than I'll speak.

sp.speaker: King
sp.ab: But wilt thou not speak all thou knowest?

sp.speaker: Parolles
sp.ab: Yes, so please your majesty. I did go between
them, as I said; but more than that, he loved
her: for indeed he was mad for her, and talked
of Satan and of Limbo and of Furies and I know
not what: yet I was in that credit with them at
that time that I knew of their going to bed, and
of other motions, as promising her marriage, and
things which would derive me ill will to speak of;
therefore I will not speak what I know.

sp.speaker: King
sp.ab: Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst
say they are married: but thou art too fine in thy
evidence; therefore stand aside.
sp.l: This ring, you say, was yours?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Where did you buy it? or who gave it you?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Who lent it you?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: It was not lent me neither.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Where did you find it then?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I found it not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: If it were yours by none of all these ways,
How could you give it him?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I never gave it him.

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: This woman's an easy glove, my lord; she goes off and
on at pleasure.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This ring was mine; I gave it his first wife.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: It might be yours or hers, for aught I know.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Take her away; I do not like her now;
To prison with her: and away with him.
Unless thou tell'st me where thou hadst this ring,
Thou diest within this hour.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I'll never tell you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Take her away.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: I'll put in bail, my liege.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I think thee now some common customer.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: By Jove, if ever I knew man, 'twas you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Wherefore hast thou accused him all this while?

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Because he's guilty, and he is not guilty:
He knows I am no maid, and he'll swear to't;
I'll swear I am a maid, and he knows not.
Great king, I am no strumpet, by my life;
I am either maid, or else this old man's wife.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: She does abuse our ears: to prison with her.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir: Exit Widow.
The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for,
And he shall surety me. But for this lord,
Who hath abused me, as he knows himself,
Though yet he never harmed me, here I quit him:
He knows himself my bed he hath defiled;
And at that time he got his wife with child:
Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick:
So there's my riddle: one that's dead is quick:
And now behold the meaning. Re-enter Widow, with HELENA.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is there no exorcist
Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes?
Is't real that I see?

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: No, my good lord;
'Tis but the shadow of a wife you see.
The name and not the thing.

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: Both, both. O, pardon!

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: O my good lord, when I was like this maid,
I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring;
And, look you, here's your letter; this it says:
âWhen from my finger you can get this ring
And are by me with child,â etc. This is done:
Will you be mine, now you are doubly won?

sp.speaker: Bertram
sp.l: If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly,
I'll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

sp.speaker: Helena
sp.l: If it appear not plain and prove untrue,
Deadly divorce step between me and you!
O my dear mother, do I see you living?

sp.speaker: Lafeu
sp.ab: Mine eyes smell onions; I shall weep anon:
Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher: so, I thank
thee: wait on me home, I'll make sport with thee: Let
thy curtsies alone, they are scurvy ones.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let us from point to point this story know,
To make the even truth in pleasure flow. To Diana
If thou be'st yet a fresh uncropped flower,
Choose thou thy husband, and I'll pay thy dower;
For I can guess that by thy honest aid
Thou kept'st a wife herself, thyself a maid.
Of that and all the progress, more and less,
Resolvedly more leisure shall express:
All yet seems well; and if it end so meet,
The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet. Flourish. EPILOGUE.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The king's a beggar, now the play is done:
All is well ended, if this suit be won,
That you express content; which we will pay,
With strife to please you, day exceeding day:
Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;
Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts. Exeunt.
